title: I produced a catchy song having samples from a dialogue from an old movie. If I used vocoder on these samples would I still need to get permission? - Quora

response.answer_text: Regardless of how you process it, it's still their content. Vocoder or not (and why not just use a formant filter… did you pipe the audio right into the mic or what?), you'll need their permission. The good news is that provided that you're respectful and not trying to steal something of genuine value from them. “The Force will be with you. Always.” is going to be harder to secure rights to than will be “You came in that thing? You're braver than I thought.” (even though the second one could really work for a pumping dance floor track… but I digress ). Also, securing the rights to samples may seem like a headache up front, but it's not nearly as bad as trying to secure them against court-ordered sanctions if your little track suddenly gets huge. That'll take the wind out of your sails really fast. Often, they'll only require credit and perhaps review (how you handle the second quote above, for example, could make that one go either way). They're not going to look for royalties or any financial compensation unless it's something like the first quote above where literally you'd be profiting from one of their most iconic pieces of audio. In the future, consider recording a friend with a good voice saying a line that sounds like it came from a movie, throw in some effects, and nobody will know it's not from a movie… they'll just think that they can't recall what movie it's from. I've seen that done dozens of times.

Yes, absolutely. Not only that, but sometimes copyright holders are not kind to those who alter the original sound files. Just to be safe I woukd ask permission. Then you won't have to worry about anything coming back to bite you later. Eventually, as technology increases, it will be harder and harder to escape copywriter infringement. Just be up front and you will be fine.
